Curator's comments: Walker & Higgs 2001 The gold pentadrachm, or trichryson (so named because it was worth three gold staters, equal to sixty silver drachms) was the standard gold denomination under Ptolemy I, but was replaced, as shown by a famous papyrus in Cairo (P.Cairo.Zen. 59021), in the reign of Ptolemy II. Bibliography: G.K. Jenkins, 'The monetary systems in the early Hellenistic time with special regard to the economic policy of the Ptolemaic kings', in A. Kindler (ed.), 'Proceedings of the International Numismatic Convention, Jerusalem, 27-31 December 1963' (Jerusalem, 1967), p. 53-72.
Bibliographic references: Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (67)
Associated names: Representation of: Ptolemy I Soter I
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Mrs G E M Lewis
